questions.text: Who wrote 'Pride and Prejudice'?
questions.explanation: Jane Austen published Pride and Prejudice in 1813.

questions.text: In which Shakespeare play does the character Puck appear?
questions.explanation: Puck, also called Robin Goodfellow, is a mischievous fairy in A Midsummer Night's Dream.

questions.text: What is the first book in the Harry Potter series?
questions.explanation: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone was published in 1997.

questions.text: Who wrote 'One Hundred Years of Solitude'?
questions.explanation: Gabriel Garcia Marquez published this landmark of magical realism in 1967.

questions.text: Which novel begins with the line 'Call me Ishmael'?

options.A: The Old Man and the Sea

questions.explanation: Moby-Dick by Herman Melville opens with this famous line.

questions.text: Who is the author of 'The Great Gatsby'?
questions.explanation: F. Scott Fitzgerald published The Great Gatsby in 1925.

questions.text: What literary genre is associated with authors like H.P. Lovecraft?
questions.explanation: H.P. Lovecraft is the father of cosmic horror, featuring incomprehensible entities and existential dread.

questions.text: Which Shakespeare play features the characters Rosencrantz and Guildenstern?
questions.explanation: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are courtiers and childhood friends of Hamlet.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Catcher in the Rye'?
questions.explanation: J.D. Salinger published The Catcher in the Rye in 1951.

questions.text: In 'Lord of the Flies', what does the conch shell symbolize?
questions.explanation: The conch shell represents democratic order and the right to speak in William Golding's novel.

questions.text: Who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1954?
questions.explanation: Ernest Hemingway won the 1954 Nobel Prize in Literature.

questions.text: What is the name of the fictional land in C.S. Lewis's fantasy series?
questions.explanation: The Chronicles of Narnia is set in the magical land of Narnia.

questions.text: Who wrote the epic poem 'Paradise Lost'?
questions.explanation: John Milton published Paradise Lost in 1667.

questions.text: Which author created the detective Sherlock Holmes?
questions.explanation: Arthur Conan Doyle first introduced Sherlock Holmes in A Study in Scarlet in 1887.

questions.text: What is the longest novel ever published in English by word count?
questions.explanation: Samuel Richardson's Clarissa (1748) is approximately 984,000 words, making it one of the longest novels in English.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Beloved'?
questions.explanation: Toni Morrison published Beloved in 1987 and won the Pulitzer Prize for it.

questions.text: In which century was 'The Canterbury Tales' written?
questions.explanation: Geoffrey Chaucer wrote The Canterbury Tales in the late 14th century, around 1387-1400.

questions.text: What is the name of Captain Ahab's ship in 'Moby-Dick'?
questions.explanation: Captain Ahab commands the whaling ship Pequod in Melville's novel.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Handmaid's Tale'?
questions.explanation: Margaret Atwood published The Handmaid's Tale in 1985.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT one of Shakespeare's tragedies?
questions.explanation: Much Ado About Nothing is a comedy. The others are all tragedies.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Odyssey'?
questions.explanation: The Odyssey is attributed to the ancient Greek poet Homer.

questions.text: What is the pen name of Samuel Clemens?
questions.explanation: Samuel Langhorne Clemens wrote under the pen name Mark Twain.

questions.text: In 'To Kill a Mockingbird', what is the name of Scout's father?
questions.explanation: Atticus Finch is the lawyer father of Scout and Jem in Harper Lee's novel.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Crime and Punishment'?
questions.explanation: Fyodor Dostoevsky published Crime and Punishment in 1866.

questions.text: What is the name of the pig who leads the rebellion in 'Animal Farm'?
questions.explanation: Old Major inspires the animals to rebel. Napoleon and Snowball later lead, but Old Major starts the rebellion.

questions.text: Which poet wrote 'The Road Not Taken'?
questions.explanation: Robert Frost published The Road Not Taken in 1916.

questions.text: Who is the author of 'Brave New World'?
questions.explanation: Aldous Huxley published Brave New World in 1932.

questions.text: What was the first published novel, often considered as such in English literature?
questions.explanation: Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe (1719) is widely considered one of the first English novels.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Divine Comedy'?
questions.explanation: Dante Alighieri wrote The Divine Comedy in the early 14th century.

questions.text: What is the setting of Emily Bronte's 'Wuthering Heights'?
questions.explanation: Wuthering Heights is set on the Yorkshire moors in northern England.

questions.text: Which children's book features a character named Thing One and Thing Two?
questions.explanation: Thing One and Thing Two appear in Dr. Seuss's The Cat in the Hat.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Don Quixote'?
questions.explanation: Miguel de Cervantes published Don Quixote in two parts in 1605 and 1615.

questions.text: What literary device is used in the phrase 'the wind whispered'?
questions.explanation: Personification gives human qualities to non-human things. Wind cannot literally whisper.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Frankenstein'?
questions.explanation: Mary Shelley published Frankenstein in 1818 when she was just 20 years old.

questions.text: What is the subtitle of 'Frankenstein'?
questions.explanation: The full title is Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus.

questions.text: Which author wrote both 'The Jungle Book' and 'Kim'?
questions.explanation: Rudyard Kipling wrote The Jungle Book (1894) and Kim (1901).

questions.text: In Greek mythology, what is the Iliad primarily about?
questions.explanation: Homer's Iliad focuses on events during the Trojan War, specifically the wrath of Achilles.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Bell Jar'?
questions.explanation: Sylvia Plath published The Bell Jar in 1963 under the pseudonym Victoria Lucas.

questions.text: What type of poem is a fourteen-line poem with a specific rhyme scheme?
questions.explanation: A sonnet is a 14-line poem, typically in iambic pentameter with a set rhyme scheme.

questions.text: Who is the author of 'Slaughterhouse-Five'?
questions.explanation: Kurt Vonnegut published Slaughterhouse-Five in 1969, based partly on his WWII experiences.

questions.text: Which Nobel Prize-winning author wrote 'The Old Man and the Sea'?
questions.explanation: Ernest Hemingway published The Old Man and the Sea in 1952.

questions.text: What is the name of the land where Bilbo Baggins lives?
questions.explanation: Bilbo Baggins lives in Bag End in the Shire in J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Invisible Man' (1952)?
questions.explanation: Ralph Ellison published Invisible Man in 1952, winning the National Book Award.

questions.text: How many plays did Shakespeare write?
questions.explanation: Shakespeare is generally credited with 37 plays, though some scholars debate the exact number.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Picture of Dorian Gray'?
questions.explanation: Oscar Wilde published The Picture of Dorian Gray in 1890.

questions.text: Which Russian novel features the characters Anna and Count Vronsky?
questions.explanation: Anna Karenina by Leo Tolstoy centers on Anna's affair with Count Vronsky.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Color Purple'?
questions.explanation: Alice Walker published The Color Purple in 1982 and won the Pulitzer Prize.

questions.text: What is a bildungsroman?
questions.explanation: A bildungsroman is a novel that follows the protagonist's growth from youth to adulthood.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Things Fall Apart'?
questions.explanation: Chinua Achebe published Things Fall Apart in 1958, a landmark of African literature.

questions.text: Which poet wrote 'I Wandered Lonely as a Cloud'?
questions.explanation: William Wordsworth wrote this poem, also known as Daffodils, in 1804.

questions.text: What is the name of Jay Gatsby's love interest in 'The Great Gatsby'?
questions.explanation: Jay Gatsby is in love with Daisy Buchanan throughout the novel.

questions.text: Who wrote 'A Tale of Two Cities'?
questions.explanation: Charles Dickens published A Tale of Two Cities in 1859, set during the French Revolution.

questions.text: Which literary movement is associated with writers like Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg?
questions.explanation: Kerouac and Ginsberg were central figures of the Beat Generation in the 1950s.

questions.text: Who wrote the children's book 'Charlotte's Web'?
questions.explanation: E.B. White published Charlotte's Web in 1952.

questions.text: What is the name of the monster in the Anglo-Saxon epic poem 'Beowulf'?
questions.explanation: Grendel is the first monster that Beowulf fights in the epic poem.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Mrs Dalloway'?
questions.explanation: Virginia Woolf published Mrs Dalloway in 1925, using a stream-of-consciousness style.

questions.text: Which Shakespeare play is set in Verona and features two feuding families?
questions.explanation: Romeo and Juliet is set in Verona and features the Montagues and Capulets.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Catch-22'?
questions.explanation: Joseph Heller published Catch-22 in 1961, set during World War II.

questions.text: What is the real name of George Orwell?
questions.explanation: George Orwell was born Eric Arthur Blair in 1903.

questions.text: Which novel by Kazuo Ishiguro features a butler named Stevens?

options.C: An Artist of the Floating World

questions.explanation: The Remains of the Day (1989) follows the butler Stevens and won the Booker Prize.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Raven'?
questions.explanation: Edgar Allan Poe published The Raven in 1845.

questions.text: What was the first book printed using movable type in Europe?
questions.explanation: The Gutenberg Bible, printed by Johannes Gutenberg around 1455, was the first major book printed with movable type in Europe.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Wuthering Heights'?
questions.explanation: Emily Bronte published Wuthering Heights in 1847, her only novel.

questions.text: Which dystopian novel features a society divided into factions based on virtues?
questions.explanation: Veronica Roth's Divergent features factions: Abnegation, Dauntless, Erudite, Amity, and Candor.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Stranger' (L'Etranger)?
questions.explanation: Albert Camus published The Stranger in 1942, a key existentialist novel.

questions.text: What children's book features a very hungry caterpillar?

options.D: If You Give a Mouse a Cookie

questions.explanation: Eric Carle published The Very Hungry Caterpillar in 1969.

questions.text: Which author created the fictional county of Yoknapatawpha?
questions.explanation: William Faulkner set many of his novels in the fictional Yoknapatawpha County, Mississippi.

questions.text: Who wrote 'The Tale of Peter Rabbit'?
questions.explanation: Beatrix Potter published The Tale of Peter Rabbit in 1902.

questions.text: Which American poet wrote 'Leaves of Grass'?
questions.explanation: Walt Whitman first published Leaves of Grass in 1855 and revised it throughout his life.

questions.text: What genre is 'Dune' by Frank Herbert?
questions.explanation: Dune (1965) is a landmark science fiction novel set on the desert planet Arrakis.

questions.text: Who wrote 'Jane Eyre'?
questions.explanation: Charlotte Bronte published Jane Eyre in 1847 under the pen name Currer Bell.

questions.text: Which poet wrote 'Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night'?
questions.explanation: Dylan Thomas wrote this villanelle, first published in 1951.

questions.text: What is the name of the Bronte sisters' fictional world they created as children?
questions.explanation: Charlotte and Branwell created Angria, while Emily and Anne created Gondal.

questions.text: Who is the author of 'The Metamorphosis'?
questions.explanation: Franz Kafka published The Metamorphosis in 1915, about Gregor Samsa turning into an insect.

questions.text: Which novel features the character of Hester Prynne?
questions.explanation: Hester Prynne is the protagonist of Nathaniel Hawthorne's The Scarlet Letter (1850).

questions.text: Who was the first African American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature?
questions.explanation: Toni Morrison won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993.

questions.text: What is the title of Roald Dahl's book about a boy who visits a chocolate factory?
questions.explanation: Roald Dahl published Charlie and the Chocolate Factory in 1964.

questions.text: Which ancient Greek wrote the tragedies 'Oedipus Rex' and 'Antigone'?
questions.explanation: Sophocles wrote both Oedipus Rex and Antigone in the 5th century BCE.

questions.text: Who wrote 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'?
questions.explanation: Ken Kesey published One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest in 1962.

questions.text: What literary term describes a story within a story?
questions.explanation: A frame narrative is a story that contains another story within it, like The Canterbury Tales.
